title: Rafters - attitude toward the past and future

content.description:
In Butler E. Brewton’s poem “Rafters,” published in 1995, the speaker reflects on family history. Read the poem carefully. Then, in a well-written essay, analyze how Brewton uses literary elements and techniques to convey the speaker’s complex attitude toward the past and future.
In your response you should do the following:

Respond to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation.

Select and use evidence to support your line of reasoning.

Explain how the evidence supports your line of reasoning.

Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your argument.

Rafters

The barn,

Gray and rotting where

The edges touch the wet earth,

Is filled to the rafters with things

5We put away from one year to the next;

And out in the field,

Half hidden by the wild sprouts,

Is the old plow my father left

The last year he planted the crop

10We deserted, never harvesting

What his sweat was meant for,

But left one by one for the factories,

Taking wives and husbands to make

Homes where the work was good

15In the cities.

I think about the hot summer streets

When we sat on the cement stoops

Drinking beer on paydays

While our children grew farther

20From our reach and one day

So far they could not hear

The sound of our voices calling

Through the night.

And I know now that what

25We came for we didn't get,

And we have put away whatever

Plans we had.

I will leave the city

And try to pull the old plow

30Out of the land,

Fix the bottom of the barn

With aged hands.
“Rafters” by Butler E. Brewton, from Home is Where: An Anthology of African American Poetry from the Carolinas. © 1995, Hub City Press. Used with permission.
